blocks.text: from which \( H_i = a \log \frac{T_2 - t_i}{T_2 - t_f} \)
Now the total heat received = \( H_i + H_f = a \log \frac{T_2 - t_i}{T_2 - t_f} + a \log \frac{T_1 - t_i}{T_1 - t_f} \)

blocks.latex: \psi = a \log \frac{T_2 - t_i}{T_2 - t_f} + a \log \frac{T_1 - t_i}{T_1 - t_f} = a \log \left(\frac{(T_2 - t_i)(T_1 - t_i)}{(T_2 - t_f)(T_1 - t_f)}\right)\text{ [where } a = 1437 \text{ and } b = R\text{]   }.
blocks.description: This equation relates the heat received to the temperature variables and constants involved.

blocks.text: Example 8 ... to prove that the equation for adiabatic expansion of air is \( v = \frac{C}{P} \), where ... specific heat at constant pressure \( K_c \), specific heat at constant volume \( K_v \).
Dealing throughout with the whole air, let the air expand under constant pressure from conditions: \( p_1, v_1 \) to \( p_2, v_2 \) .
Then the heat added =  \( K_c (t_f - t_i) \) = \( K_c (r_f - r_i) \)
Now keep the volume constant at  \( v \) and subtract as much heat as was previously added - then the pressure falls to \( p_a \) and the temperature to \( t_a \) .
The heat subtracted =  \( K_f (r_f - r_i) \) =  \( K_f \cdot (v - ... ) \)
